definition: to set/to fix/to determine/to decide/to order
to pluck (a string)/to play (a string instrument)/to spring or leap/to shoot (e.g. with a catapult)/(of cotton) to fluff or tease/to flick/to flip/to accuse/to impeach/elastic (of materials)

sentences.english: The territorial issue remains the time bomb, Mr. Cole said.
sentences.chinese: 前美海軍官員伯納德說，領海問題仍是一個定時炸彈。

sentences.english: “It seems like there’s a ticking time bomb, ” Ms. Paster said.
sentences.chinese: “就像有顆定時炸彈，”帕斯特女士說。

sentences.english: By eliminating this ticking time-bomb, the possibility of serious accidents had been ruled out.
sentences.chinese: 剷除了一顆定時炸彈，避免了災難性事故的發生。

sentences.english: Basically, buried in the DNA of this ant is a little time bomb.
sentences.chinese: 基本上，這種螞蟻的基因裏埋葬着一顆定時炸彈。

sentences.english: Call it what you want: a time-bomb or a powder keg.
sentences.chinese: 甚至可以說，它就是一顆定時炸彈或火藥桶。

sentences.english: Why can't they hear this market timebomb ticking?
sentences.chinese: 爲什麼他們聽不到市場這隻定時炸彈的滴答聲呢？

definition: to shoot accidentally while polishing a gun/(fig.) a minor incident that sparks a war
to die (idiom)/to breathe one's last/to give up the ghost
to be unable to withstand a single blow/to collapse at the first blow
fuse (for explosives)/(fig.) proximate cause/the last straw
to charge and break through enemy lines
seize every minute and second (idiom); not a minute to lose/every moment counts
it will cause no end of trouble (idiom)
see 百孔千瘡|百孔千疮[bai3 kong3 qian1 chuang1]
